a.g: When the sun is wrapped up [in darkness]
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book3
Indeed, when Umar, may God be pleased with him, recited, "When the sun is wound up [kawwira]," and reached the saying of God, the Exalted, "And when the records are spread open [nushirat]," he fell down unconscious. And how could all the believers not fear, when He, glory be to Him, says: "Surah Hud and its sisters have aged me" — meaning Surah Al-Waqi'ah, "When the sun is wound up [kawwira]," and "About what do they question one another?" And in Surah At-Takwir are the terrors [ahwal] of the Day of Resurrection and the unveiling [inkishaf] of the final outcome, which is His saying, the Exalted: "And when the Hellfire is set ablaze [su'irat], and when Paradise is brought near [uzlifat], a soul [nafs] will know what it has brought forth."

a.g: And when the stars fall, dispersing,
And when the mountains are removed
And when full-term she-camels are neglected
And when the wild beasts are gathered
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book10
Indeed, at that moment, the wild beasts [al-wuhush] from the wilderness and the mountains will come forth, their heads bowed low, mingled with the creatures after their wildness, humbled for the Day of Resurrection [Yawm al-Nushur], not due to any sin [khati'a] with which they were defiled. Rather, their gathering [hashrahum] is due to the intensity of the Blast [al-sa'iqah] and the terror of the Trumpet Blast [al-nafkhah], and that preoccupies them from fleeing from the creation and from their wildness towards them. And that is His Exalted saying: "And when the wild beasts are gathered."

a.g: And when the seas are filled with flame
And when the souls are paired
And when the girl [who was] buried alive is asked
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

j2 k02
Indeed, then He recited His saying, the Exalted, in the Verse: "And when the buried-alive [al-maw'udah] is asked." (81:8). So if you say: "He, peace and blessings be upon him, has indeed said regarding *al-'azl* (coitus interruptus): 'That is the hidden infanticide [al-wa'd al-khafiy],' and he recited 'And when the buried-alive [al-maw'udah] is asked.' And this is in the *Sahih*. And his saying 'the hidden infanticide [al-wa'd al-khafiy]' is like his saying 'the hidden polytheism [al-shirk al-khafiy],' and that necessitates dislike [karahah], not prohibition [tahrim]." So if you say: "Ibn 'Abbas has indeed said: '*Al-'azl* is the lesser infanticide [al-wa'd al-asghar], for what is prevented from existing by it is the lesser buried-alive [al-maw'udah al-sughra].'" We say: This is an analogy [qiyas] from him to negate the existence [wujud] by cutting it off, and it is a weak analogy [qiyas]. And for that reason, 'Ali, may God be pleased with him, objected to him when he heard it. He said: "And she does not become a buried-alive [maw'udah] except after seven," meaning after the other seven stages [atwar]. And he recited the Verse that comes regarding the stages [atwar] of creation, and it is His saying, the Exalted: ("And We have certainly created man from an extract of clay. Then We placed him as a sperm-drop [nutfah] in a firm resting place...") until His saying ("...Then We produced him as another creation.") (23:12-14) – meaning, We blew into him the spirit [al-ruh]. Then he recited His saying, the Exalted, in the Verse: "And when the buried-alive [al-maw'udah] is asked."
j2 k02
Indeed, then He recited His saying, the Exalted, in the Verse: "And when the buried-alive [al-maw'udah] is asked." (81:8). So if you say: "He, peace and blessings be upon him, has indeed said regarding *al-'azl* (coitus interruptus): 'That is the hidden infanticide [al-wa'd al-khafiy],' and he recited 'And when the buried-alive [al-maw'udah] is asked.' And this is in the *Sahih*. And his saying 'the hidden infanticide [al-wa'd al-khafiy]' is like his saying 'the hidden polytheism [al-shirk al-khafiy],' and that necessitates dislike [karahah], not prohibition [tahrim]." So if you say: "Ibn 'Abbas has indeed said: '*Al-'azl* is the lesser infanticide [al-wa'd al-asghar], for what is prevented from existing by it is the lesser buried-alive [al-maw'udah al-sughra].'" We say: This is an analogy [qiyas] from him to negate the existence [wujud] by cutting it off, and it is a weak analogy [qiyas]. And for that reason, 'Ali, may God be pleased with him, objected to him when he heard it. He said: "And she does not become a buried-alive [maw'udah] except after seven," meaning after the other seven stages [atwar]. And he recited the Verse that comes regarding the stages [atwar] of creation, and it is His saying, the Exalted: ("And We have certainly created man from an extract of clay. Then We placed him as a sperm-drop [nutfah] in a firm resting place...") until His saying ("...Then We produced him as another creation.") (23:12-14) – meaning, We blew into him the spirit [al-ruh]. Then he recited His saying, the Exalted, in the Verse: "And when the buried-alive [al-maw'udah] is asked."

a.g: For what sin she was killed
And when the pages are made public
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book3
Indeed, when Umar, may God be pleased with him, recited, "When the sun is wrapped up [kawwira]," and reached the saying of God, the Exalted, "And when the records [al-suhuf] are spread open [nushirat]," he fell down unconscious.

a.g: And when the sky is stripped away
And when Hellfire is set ablaze
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book3
Indeed, in the Chapter of the Rolling Up [at-Takwir], there are the terrors of the Day of Resurrection [Yawm al-Qiyamah] and the unveiling of the final outcome [al-khatimah]. And that is His, the Exalted's, saying: "And when the Blazing Fire [al-Jahim] is set ablaze, and when Paradise [al-Jannah] is brought near, a soul [nafs] will know what it has brought forth."

a.g: And when Paradise is brought near,
A soul will [then] know what it has brought [with it].
So I swear by the retreating stars -
Those that run [their courses] and disappear -
And by the night as it closes in
And by the dawn when it breathes
a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 10
Indeed, the path [tariq] to God, the Exalted, is the vigilant observance [muraqaba] of times and their cultivation [imara] with regular devotions [awrad] in a manner of constancy [dawam]. For among the times of nobility [sharaf] is what is between the rising of dawn [subh] and the rising of the sun, since God, the Exalted, swore by it in His saying: "And by the dawn [subh] when it breathes," to indicate its virtue [fadl] and its honor [karama]. Therefore, it is incumbent upon the believer [mu'min] to occupy himself within it with remembrance [dhikr] and obedience [ta'a], beginning with awakening and supplication [du'a'], then ablution [wudu'] and prayer [salah], striving for the commerce [tijara] of the Abode of the Hereafter [dar al-akhira] and seeking the bounty [fadl] of God and His good pleasure [ridwan].

a.g: [That] indeed, the Qur'an is a word [conveyed by] a noble messenger
[Who is] possessed of power and with the Owner of the Throne, secure [in position],
Obeyed there [in the heavens] and trustworthy.
And your companion is not [at all] mad.
And he has already seen Gabriel in the clear horizon.
And Muhammad is not a withholder of [knowledge of] the unseen.
And the Qur'an is not the word of a devil, expelled [from the heavens].
So where are you going?
It is not except a reminder to the worlds
For whoever wills among you to take a right course.
And you do not will except that Allah wills - Lord of the worlds.
